I know you well enough: I know that you lead your colleagues in the royal court, that you are the author of all the harm done in <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>, and that if you used your intellect for good, no one would be better suited than you to bring about the fusion we aim to achieve. – I am thinking about it, Mr. Bissette; and perhaps you believe I came to France to block the appeal of the condemned from <tei-placeName ref="#GdA" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Grand’Anse</tei-placeName>. I accompanied <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Duclary</tei-persName>, who is going to <tei-placeName ref="#Bor" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Bordeaux</tei-placeName> to fetch his son to enroll him in a boarding school here in Paris. Well, I give you my word of honor that I will not make a single move against the condemned. – That is wise; as for me, I am already attending to those unfortunate individuals, and I will continue to do so. I can already tell you that not a single head will fall; no scaffold will be raised for any of them, and not one will go to the galleys. – I hope so. – It will happen. – <tei-persName ref="#FA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Fabien</tei-persName> has treated me abominably in his writings. – And you, how did you treat him? Did you not brand him too, despite his appeal to cassation? He has not said a single untruth about you. You always retreat into your judicial functions, and when your acts as a magistrate are criticized, you fall back into your conscience as a man. Well, I will address both aspects. It was as Attorney General that you summoned my wife to your office, escorted by two gendarmes, to seize a letter—the last comfort I had left for her and my children. That letter, as you know, was written upon leaving the execution site. My shoulder was still burning; the brand that you had ordered the executioner to apply was still fresh; yet I wrote, despite the fever, urging forgiveness—for you and for my judges. The very forgiveness of the past that you now seek, I was advocating for then. I comforted my wife and children with religious sentiments, with Christian charity; and you had the audacity to threaten this unfortunate woman, who was without support, to tear her away from her children, to make her endure my fate, to send her to the galleys, if she did not hand over that letter to you. You had no pity for her plight; she presented you with an eight-month-old infant she was nursing, hoping to touch your heart, if not as a magistrate, then as a man; yet nothing could sway you... She yielded to your threats and your gendarmes, gave you the letter, and you burned it after reading it. That was outside your judicial functions. Answer this, sir; is it not vile of you to have exploited a woman’s grief, to torment her in all her affections and even in her sources of consolation? Was it the magistrate or the man who burned the letter? You are silent, sir, answer me! – I admit I was wrong, and I reproach myself for that act, but perhaps I can find some excuse in the widespread agitation at the time. – Call it terror for some and rage for others. – There was no rage, but effervescence. – There was both. – For my part, Mr. Bissette, I did not know you or Mr. Fabien; I could not harbor any resentment against you or act out of hatred. But let us forget all this past; see if your name has ever been mentioned even once in the trial of the Grand’Anse. – But you always evade the questions, Mr. Lucy. Well! I will tell you that my name appears twice in the indictment. -What is <tei-pb facs="v1n4f35" n="35" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>the indictment? Certainly, the men of color from Grand’Anse may have mentioned your name, like that of M. Léonce, in their speeches; but see if the proceedings took it into account. M. Léonce was acquitted, as I already told you, unanimously. Today, in Martinique, all wise men want and desire reconciliation. -Why don’t you bring about this reconciliation? You will never achieve it with your capital punishments. Well, sir, I believe, and it is my opinion, that you and a few other colonists are the only obstacles to fusion. If you sincerely want it as I do, and without ulterior motives, let us each act on our side to make it happen; I will renounce my sentiments, personal as they are, regarding what I feel against you: I will silence in my heart this sentiment that I could not repress when seeing you. And it is not hatred, sir, as you claim, it is something worse. I would consent, in the interest of my country and my friends, to forget the harm you caused me and them, if you would act among your own people to have them renounce all resentment, all caste hatred. The men of color detest you, even though you claim they gave you votes in the elections; well, I promise to bring them back if peace is made between the two classes, if your friends will act in good faith and sincerity. It will be a noble example to see the two classes, to see me, Bissette, your <tei-emph data-origname="emph">enemy</tei-emph>, agree to forget the past to bring about reconciliation between our two groups. -Mr. Bissette, I am not your enemy. -I am yours; let me say, I would do it, but I have no confidence in the word of your people; if the treaty were made, they would be capable of assassinating me upon returning to the country. -Ah! Mr. Bissette, where do you see assassinations? There is no place in the world where assassination is less frequent than in the colonies, and honestly, can you cite a single case of assassination as you mean it? There are many fights, but no assassinations. The word assassination is figurative here; I mean that they would create trouble for me, start affairs, imprison me without cause to get rid of me, and thus assassinate me, not physically but morally. I have spoken, sir; but I do not absolve you; I must part from you, for the Colonial Director is waiting for me.”</tei-q></tei-p>
<tei-pb facs="v1n4f36" n="36" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>
<tei-p data-origname="p">This conversation, <tei-emph data-origname="emph">ex abrupto</tei-emph>, occurred only by chance when M. Bissette encountered M. Lucy at the Ministry of the Navy. M. Bissette, driven by an irresistible impulse and with no other aim than to confront face-to-face the dreadful Attorney General who had him BRANDED, disregarding all notions of justice and injustice, all laws then in force—no matter how detestable they may have been—and his appeal to the Court of Cassation, has reproduced the words here. Despite his reluctance to involve the public in his personal matters, he considered it vital for the truth in this regard to reach the colonies in its entirety and not be distorted by the false interpretations habitually propagated by his overseas adversaries.</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">M. Bissette wrote this conversation exactly as it is presented here, upon returning home the very evening it took place, <tei-emph data-origname="emph">ne varietur</tei-emph>. M. Bissette does not even believe he misremembered the phrasing, however verbose, of the Attorney General. In any case, he is certain that he has conveyed its meaning with the utmost fidelity. Any other version that might emerge can, in all truth, be considered false and deceitful.</tei-p></tei-div><tei-div data-origname="div">
  <tei-head data-origname="head">MISCELLANEOUS NEWS.</tei-head>

  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#DU" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Henri Dutrône</tei-persName>, counselor at the royal court of <tei-placeName ref="#Ami" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Amiens</tei-placeName>, has been tasked by the government to study in <tei-placeName ref="#Alg" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Algiers</tei-placeName> the possibilities for organizing and spreading education in this colony.</tei-p>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">-<tei-persName ref="#BA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Babe</tei-persName>, auditor-counselor at the royal court of <tei-placeName ref="#GP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Guadeloupe</tei-placeName>, has been appointed titular counselor at <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>, replacing <tei-persName ref="#Pé" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Pécoul</tei-persName>.</tei-p>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">-It is reported in the <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title data-origname="title"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">Journal de la marine</tei-emph></tei-title></tei-bibl>: A few days before the departure of <tei-persName ref="#BARC" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Captain Barbédienne</tei-persName>, commander of <tei-emph data-origname="emph">l'Aimable Lucette</tei-emph>, who left on <tei-date data-origname="date">July 17</tei-date> from <tei-placeName ref="#PàP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Pointe-à-Pitre</tei-placeName>, the news of the appointment of <tei-persName ref="#JAC" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Count Jacob</tei-persName> as Minister of the Navy was received in Guadeloupe. The 
  <tei-reg data-origname="reg">inhabitants</tei-reg>, who were administered by the admiral for 
  <tei-reg data-origname="reg">a long time</tei-reg>, were delighted by this event. However, this does not include some colonial councilors who, thinking him powerless and without influence, stripped him of his delegation duties just as he was entering the ministry and would have had to resign from them anyway. They lacked foresight and are now greatly concerned that the minister will not lack memory. They are undoubtedly mistaken: Count Jacob is not a man to hold grudges.</tei-p>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">functions of the delegate at the very moment he entered the ministry and was necessarily forced to resign them. They lacked instinct and are very much afraid that the minister does not lack memory. They are certainly wrong: Count Jacob is not a man to hold a grudge.</tei-p>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">- We are pleased to learn that a wealthy planter recently embarked from one of the ports in <tei-placeName ref="#ANG" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">England</tei-placeName> for <tei-placeName ref="#JA" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Jamaica</tei-placeName>, where he plans to completely emancipate, on <tei-date data-origname="date">August 1, 1854</tei-date>, the slaves working on his plantations. He does not doubt that the newly freed black individuals will willingly negotiate to work his lands. May this example find individuals worthy of understanding and following it!</tei-p>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">- The journal <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title ref="#Abol" data-origname="title" data-origatts="ref">Abolitionist</tei-title></tei-bibl> reveals a distressing fact. While England, in an act of generosity unparalleled in history, sacrifices its own needs to pay part of humanity's immense debt to the enslaved, there are still Englishmen vile enough to participate indirectly or directly in the slave trade. Several 
  <tei-reg data-origname="reg">merchants</tei-reg> in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">London</tei-placeName>, it is reported, have invested their capital in enterprises set up to exploit mines in South America, where enslaved Africans, abducted from their homeland, are mercilessly buried every day. <tei-q data-origname="q">“The same occurs in <tei-placeName ref="#BR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Brazil</tei-placeName>,” adds the Abolitionist: “English investors, as shareholders in similar ventures, have advanced funds to purchase around five hundred slaves employed in the country's mines.”</tei-q></tei-p>
</tei-div>
<tei-div xml:id="french-colonies" id="french-colonies" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
  <tei-head data-origname="head">FRENCH COLONIES.</tei-head>
  <tei-head data-origname="head">MARTINIQUE</tei-head>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">We are writing from Saint-Pierre:
  <tei-q data-origname="q">The reaction here has been so complete since the infamous ruling in the case of <tei-placeName ref="#GdA" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Grand'Anse</tei-placeName> that our privileged officials have no qualms about violating all laws; they are advancing rapidly from persecution to the most revolting arbitrariness. The prosecutor of the king, <tei-persName ref="#AuA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Aubert-Armand</tei-persName>, is making the young <tei-persName ref="#Louisy" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Louisy</tei-persName> (this <tei-emph data-origname="emph">patroné</tei-emph>, whose trial caused such an uproar and who won the annulment of the ruling sentencing him to the galleys) pay for the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">grave offense of displeasing his judges by appealing their ruling</tei-emph>. <tei-persName ref="#Louisy" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Louisy</tei-persName>, wishing to regularize his freedom papers, requested authorization from the prosecutor of the king to register in the civil registry; this official refused, saying Louisy is a <tei-emph data-origname="emph">bad</tei-emph> subject who has no document to justify his status as a free man. We replied that the lengthy legal proceedings before the colony’s courts and the Court of Cassation were sufficient to prove his <tei-emph data-origname="emph">patroné</tei-emph> status and that no document was required other than proof of identity. When <tei-persName ref="#AuA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Aubert-Armand</tei-persName> asked for the militia enlistment document Louisy had obtained, we responded that this piece had been included in the file sent to the Court of Cassation, which should now be at the registry of the royal court in the colony. A petition was addressed to the prosecutor general, <tei-persName ref="#ANog" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Arsène Nogues</tei-persName>, to retrieve this document, but the petitioner was disgracefully dismissed by this magistrate: "You come here, claiming your papers? Do you think you’re free?" Louisy had the good sense to reply that the Court of Cassation had recognized him as such: "No," retorted Mr. Nogues, "you are nothing but a slave. Did you get your master's permission to come here? You had the audacity to strike a white man; the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">mulattos</tei-emph> snuck you a fake enlistment paper in your prison, and now you dare demand this title from me? Get out of here before I send you to jail."</tei-q></tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">This disgraceful behavior by this magistrate hardly inspires respect. Furthermore, the sentiment we feel for Mr. Nogues is far from that of esteem. Can one go further in disregarding decorum? A magistrate, a prosecutor general, who stoops to rejecting a plaintiff’s claim with insults and invective, and who seems to reproach someone he failed to send to the galleys for winning the annulment of the monstrous ruling rendered on his conclusions. Truly, my dear friend, if one could regret the <tei-persName ref="#RL" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">RICHARD-Lucy</tei-persName>s and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Dessalles</tei-persName>s, no one would make us regret them more than Mr. Arsène Nogues. These three men certainly stand on equal footing, and <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName> 
  <tei-reg data-origname="reg">will long</tei-reg> remember their actions as public prosecutors.</tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">We are writing from Fort-Royal:
  It has been impossible for us to see or communicate with the unfortunate <tei-persName ref="#Cé" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Césaire</tei-persName>, who has been in solitary confinement since his transfer from Saint-Pierre to <tei-placeName ref="#FoR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Fort-Royal</tei-placeName>. It was only when representatives entered the prison to secure a general proxy for the condemned in the Grand'Anse case that they managed to slip him an indicative note for his authorization. The next day, he was placed in the same room as the other prisoners, where he was finally able to meet with the notary to draft the proxy as intended, to contest the ruling, if necessary, by invoking falsehood. All the condemned are shackled and endure the most cruel 
  <tei-reg data-origname="reg">treatment</tei-reg>.</tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">RICHARD-LUCY and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Duclary</tei-persName> are leaving for France; they will likely defend the death sentence they pronounced in the Grand'Anse case. Lucy, it is said, intends to pull every string to secure a position at the <tei-orgName ref="#CDC" data-origname="orgName" data-origatts="ref">Court of Cassation</tei-orgName>, whether as counselor or as advocate general. It would not be surprising if he counted among his credentials for this high office the vile act of having, as prosecutor general in 1824, executed on you and your companions the infamous sentence condemning you to branding and perpetual galleys, despite your appeal to the Court of Cassation. Lucy relies heavily on the protection of Admiral Jacob, now Minister of the Navy and Colonies; but we cannot believe that the minister’s protection would stoop so low. By supporting RICHARD-LUCY’s ambitions, the minister of the <tei-rs type="event" data-origname="rs" data-origatts="type">July Revolution</tei-rs> would be doing what the ministers of the Restoration never dared.</tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">Another letter from Fort-Royal states:
  Prosecutor General Nogues is exceedingly harsh toward the Grand'Anse detainees. These unfortunate individuals are only allowed to communicate with their families on Thursdays. He put poor Césaire in solitary confinement because he called a notary to draft a proxy to contest an incidental ruling by the Saint-Pierre Assizes Court. Mr. Nogues searched Césaire, found an explanatory note on him regarding what he needed to do to obtain this document, and told him he would remain in solitary confinement until he revealed who had given him the note.</tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">One of the Grand'Anse convicts who had been in the hospital for eight days has just died. It is Mr. Sainte-Rose-Barthel, sentenced to five years of imprisonment. His family, through our intervention, made requests to the authorities to claim his body for burial, but even this sad consolation was denied. He was buried by the chain gang!</tei-p>
</tei-div>
<tei-div data-origname="div">
  <tei-head data-origname="head">
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">GUYANE</tei-reg>.
  </tei-head>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">A report from <tei-placeName ref="#Cay" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Cayenne</tei-placeName>, dated <tei-date data-origname="date">August 3</tei-date>, states:
  For nearly two months, the outcome of disputes between two members of the court, <tei-persName ref="#PONT" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">MM. de Pontevès</tei-persName> and the attorney general Vidal de Lingendes, has been known in Cayenne. It is known that Mr. de Pontevès was dismissed in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Paris</tei-placeName> from all accusations he had thought fit to bring against the attorney general. The 
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">triumph</tei-reg>
    of the latter, the dismissal of his adversary, and his replacement by the prosecutor of the king <tei-persName ref="#Gib" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Gibelin</tei-persName>, have created an effect difficult to describe on the minds of the highly divided partisans of the two magistrates. The astonishment, to say the least, reached its peak when it was learned that the president of the royal court himself was reprimanded and invited to resign for disapproving of Mr. Vidal's conduct and expressing this disapproval frankly in his reports to the minister.</tei-p>
  
  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#PERS" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. Persegol</tei-persName> had earned esteem here for a certain independence that could not conform to the despotic tendencies of our higher authorities. On this occasion, he did not betray his character and, wasting no time, either requested or took leave, departing the colony. Resolved to offer the resignation requested of him, he left for 
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">France</tei-reg>
    to justify his conduct and prove that, in the reports where he is accused of distorting the facts that occurred before his eyes and in which he had been a principal actor, he had written nothing but the exact truth.</tei-p>
  
  <tei-p data-origname="p">Thus, the royal court of 
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">Guyane</tei-reg>
    , barely established, is already in disarray. Four magistrates out of seven who constitute it have been put out of office. Yesterday, <tei-date data-origname="date">August 2</tei-date>, one could read in our gazette an adoption ruling signed by six judges, four of whom were acting in provisional, honorary, or interim capacities. Given such a composition, could one suspect that there exists an ordinance, too recent to have already fallen into disuse, which established a sovereign court among us and appointed its members, whose salaries appear in our colonial budget at nearly 70,000 francs?</tei-p>
  
  <tei-p data-origname="p">The 
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">Guyane</tei-reg>
    , like the island of Bourbon, is a colony filled with 
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">independent</tei-reg>
    and liberal minds. The <tei-rs type="event" data-origname="rs" data-origatts="type">July Revolution</tei-rs> was warmly received here; but the triumph of the faction governing us has, in recent days, made even the boldest lower their heads. You can imagine the prestige such successes create in a small locality. People tremble at the thought of provoking complaints from individuals who are always given the benefit of the doubt because they are aligned with those in power, which refuses to admit error. Later, of course, reparations are made for those who were unjustly targeted. This is how <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Boyer</tei-persName>, a counselor, was transferred with a higher salary from Guyane to <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>
  
  <tei-p data-origname="p">It is unclear what will become of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">MM. Pontevès</tei-persName> and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Persegol</tei-persName>. What is certain is that their departure from Cayenne is a true source of grief for those who wish to see at least the independence of the judiciary respected. We wholeheartedly call for legislation on this important subject. Nothing is more vital for our colonies. No one can sleep peacefully with courts that a governor or attorney general can dismantle at will. Justice must finally leave the domain of the marine administration and come under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Justice. This is a reform long 
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">overdue</tei-reg>.
    Let us hope that the scenes enacted in our royal court, the 
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">clarifications</tei-reg>
    and debates resulting from the case bringing Mr. Persegol to Paris, will at least enlighten the government's opinion and raise this significant issue in Parliament.</tei-p>
</tei-div>
<tei-div data-origname="div">
  <tei-head data-origname="head">BOURBON.</tei-head>
  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q">“..... As I write to you, the entire city is in a state of great agitation. The question that has preoccupied everyone for 
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">so long</tei-reg>
    is about to be resolved: which faction will prevail?..... the opposition or the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">moderates</tei-emph>? 
    This means that the general council, convened in an extraordinary session, is currently focused on the election of our delegates. 
    A significant number of candidates have been put forward by both the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">moderate</tei-emph> faction and the opposition. Among these candidates, the following names are mentioned: <tei-persName data-origname="persName">MM. Legoff</tei-persName>, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Orsat</tei-persName>, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">A. Bédier</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#SuB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Sully-Brunet</tei-persName>, and <tei-persName ref="#C" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Conil</tei-persName>. The latter two have been put forward by the opposition. It is widely believed that they will be elected. A few days ago, we experienced a brief squall that caused some damage to our plantations. Fortunately, rains that followed this unfortunate event have mitigated the disaster it caused. 
    Only two ships were dismasted; one of them (<tei-emph data-origname="emph">la Lise de Bordeaux</tei-emph>) has just been condemned. 
    That is all I have to report for the moment. In my next letter, I will discuss our administration, which has suffered for far too long under the harmful influence of a family whose power has remained untouched despite the glorious <tei-rs type="event" data-origname="rs" data-origatts="type">July Revolution</tei-rs>. 
    P.S. – Just as I was about to close my letter, I was informed of the election of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">MM. Sully-Brunet</tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#C" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Conil</tei-persName>.”</tei-q></tei-p>
</tei-div>
<tei-div xml:id="foreign-colonies" id="foreign-colonies" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
  <tei-head data-origname="head">FOREIGN COLONIES.</tei-head>
  <tei-head data-origname="head">JAMAICA.</tei-head>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">The following proclamation was addressed by the new governor, the <tei-persName ref="#Sligo" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Marquis of Sligo</tei-persName>, to the island’s emancipated Black population following the new law:
    <tei-q data-origname="q">“My friends, our good king, who many years ago visited Jamaica, still thinks of our island and speaks of it often. He has sent me here to take care of you and to protect your rights. But at the same time, he has ordered me to ensure justice for your former masters and to punish those who misbehave. Follow <tei-pb facs="v1n4f43" n="43" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>my advice, for I am your friend. Be sober, honest, and diligent when your apprenticeship begins, for if you misbehave and refuse to work because you are no longer slaves, be assured that you risk punishment.
    The English people are your friends and subjects of the same monarch; they have shown this by passing the <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign">bill</tei-foreign> that grants you freedom. Your masters are also your friends; they demonstrated this by supporting the same <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign">bill</tei-foreign> in the assembly. It is up to you to prove that you are worthy of this goodwill and the benefits granted to you by the new law by working diligently during your apprenticeship.
    On <tei-date data-origname="date">August 1</tei-date>, your slavery will end! But starting from that day, your apprenticeship with your former masters will begin. This status will last for a few years, after which you will be judged worthy of full freedom. It will depend on your behavior whether your apprenticeship is shorter or longer because if you run away, you will be brought back by the maroons and the police, and your apprenticeship will be extended compared to those who behave well. You will only be required to work four and a half days per week; the remaining time will be yours to use as you please.
    Do not forget, even in your joy, that everyone must work. Some work with their hands, others with their minds, but no one is respected if they do nothing. 
    Your role is manual labor. I urge you to fulfill it faithfully, for if you neglect your duties, you will be brought before the magistrates sent by the king to oversee you, whose duty is to act impartially and administer justice by punishing those who show poor behavior.
    Do not heed the advice of the 
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">wicked</tei-reg>
    , for if any of you refuse to fulfill the requirements of the law, you will undoubtedly regret it. You will see your companions complete their apprenticeship while you are condemned to hard labor in the house of correction as punishment for your disobedience. <tei-pb facs="v1n4f44" n="44" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/> If you follow my advice and behave well, nothing will prevent you from becoming your own masters, working for yourselves, your wives, and your 
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">children</tei-reg>, after the four to six years of apprenticeship imposed based on your class.
    I cannot visit every estate on the island to tell you all this in person. That is why I have ordered my letter to be printed and read to all of you, so that you are not misled and are not driven by bad advice or ignorance of your duties and rights to actions you would come to regret.
    I trust that you will be loyal and 
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">obedient</tei-reg>
    subjects of our good king and that he will never have cause to regret the good he has done for you.
    Your friend, who desires your happiness.
    SLIGO”</tei-q>
  </tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-date data-origname="date">August 1</tei-date> was a day of widespread celebration on the island, and there was hope that all would go well. The governor's proclamation addressed to runaway slaves had a positive impact. Several hundred turned themselves in to the magistrates. The mayor spent the entire day issuing passports to those who requested them. Among the returnees was a woman who had been absent for twenty-five years and brought back four 
  <tei-reg data-origname="reg">children</tei-reg>
  with her. <tei-persName ref="#BAI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Baines</tei-persName>, a salaried magistrate, recently traveled to <tei-placeName ref="#SW" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Swansea</tei-placeName> and <tei-placeName ref="#TH" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Thetford</tei-placeName> in <tei-placeName ref="#ISJ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">St. John’s Island</tei-placeName> to explain the governor's proclamation and the 
  <tei-reg data-origname="reg">changes</tei-reg>
  in their status. His explanations and his speech were quickly mocked; Mr. Baines was loudly heckled. He had four of the main agitators arrested, and they were sent to Spanish Town. Yesterday, the magistrates began hearings on the matter. His Excellency the Governor presided over the session, and the questioning went into great detail. Two men were sentenced to forty-eight lashes each, and the other two to twelve lashes each, to be administered on the plantation. The Marquis of Sligo offered an escort to return the offenders to the plantation, but Mr. Blair, the attorney, unadvisedly declined. His Excellency gave a stern reprimand to the guilty parties and expressed his determination to rigorously suppress acts of insubordination. <tei-pb facs="v1n4f45" n="45" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>
  During a special session in the parish of <tei-placeName ref="#MC" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Manchester</tei-placeName>, a meeting was held regarding the working hours of apprentices under the new system. Several attorneys and planters presented their plans, with no complete consensus on all points. Some were more 
  <tei-reg data-origname="reg">accommodating</tei-reg>
  than others; a few allowed more time for breakfast. Generally, from April to September, work will begin at six o’clock in the morning, and from September to April, at seven. A midday break was not determined, as the laborers generally preferred having more time in the afternoon. The apprentices will work eight hours for their masters, with the remaining time available for personal use; any additional work for their masters would be paid at a fixed rate. One respectable colonist stated that he had already agreed to pay 5 pounds 
  <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign">sterling</tei-foreign>
  per year to each first-class apprentice for extra work, with others being paid proportionally. In this plantation alone, this arrangement would provide the apprentices with 650 pounds 
  <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign">sterling</tei-foreign>
  annually for their personal benefit. The governor issued an ordinance to establish a new police force in the city of <tei-placeName ref="#K" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Kingston</tei-placeName>, with plans to extend it across the entire island. Night guards have been instituted in nearly all areas to protect properties against sudden disturbances of the peace. In <tei-placeName ref="#Vé" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Vérez</tei-placeName>, magistrates convened to establish uniform regulations for the wages of apprentices starting on <tei-date data-origname="date">August 1</tei-date>. All reports agree that the events of August 1 passed without any disorder.</tei-p>
</tei-div>
<tei-div data-origname="div">
  <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#GR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">GRENADA</tei-placeName>.</tei-head>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">A letter from <tei-placeName ref="#StG" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">St. George's</tei-placeName>, dated <tei-date data-origname="date">August 3</tei-date>, reports:
  The freedom of enslaved people was proclaimed on this island on the first of this month. On two estates, a small number of workers declared they would not work unless paid like their counterparts in the <tei-placeName ref="#ANT" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">island of Antigua</tei-placeName>; however, the police quickly intervened. Since then, everything has been peaceful, and there is no expectation that this will change.</tei-p>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">I will not attempt to describe the joy that lit up the faces of those who were enslaved yesterday and are free <tei-pb facs="v1n4f46" n="46" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>today; I leave it to your imagination. Those who predicted uprisings and countless other disasters in the <tei-placeName ref="#InO" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">West Indies</tei-placeName> as a result of the emancipation of enslaved people will undoubtedly be disappointed.</tei-p>
</tei-div>

<tei-div data-origname="div">
  <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#StV" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">SAINT VINCENT</tei-placeName>.</tei-head>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">A letter from Saint Vincent, dated <tei-date data-origname="date">August 2</tei-date>, states: 
  I am pleased to report that everything here is peaceful. The newly freed individuals conducted themselves admirably yesterday.</tei-p>
</tei-div>

<tei-div data-origname="div">
  <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#ANT" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">ANTIGUA</tei-placeName>.</tei-head>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">We are eagerly awaiting the day set for the full emancipation of enslaved people. Measures have been taken to ensure that nothing disturbs the harmonious relationship that exists between masters and the formerly enslaved on this memorable day. The doors of all churches and chapels will be opened to the grateful piety of the island's great family. Religion will instill in all hearts a spirit of brotherhood and unity, tempering the enthusiasm of the Black population caused by the attainment of a long-desired freedom.</tei-p>
</tei-div>

<tei-div data-origname="div">
  <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#StC" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">SAINT CHRISTOPHER</tei-placeName>.</tei-head>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">Reports from this island do not confirm the rumors of disturbances it was said to have experienced. These <tei-emph data-origname="emph">on dits</tei-emph> appear to be unfounded.
  The <tei-date data-origname="date">1st of August</tei-date> passed as the friends and advocates of emancipation had hoped.</tei-p>
</tei-div>
<tei-div data-origname="div">
  <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#TR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">TRINIDAD</tei-placeName>.</tei-head>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">On August 1st, emancipated Black people descended into the city of <tei-placeName ref="#PE" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Port of Spain</tei-placeName> and headed toward the government palace. Upon his arrival, the governor found the crowd assembled and learned that the purpose of this gathering was to request a pause in labor. By evening, the gathering dispersed, and the night passed peacefully.
  The following morning, the emancipated individuals assembled again, seemingly undeterred by the numerous arrests made by the militia of the most 
  <tei-choice data-origname="choice">
    <tei-orig data-origname="orig">turbulens</tei-orig>
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">turbulent</tei-reg>
  </tei-choice>
  among them. The planters insisted on the proclamation of martial law, but no such measure was taken against the Black population. None of those who came to the city carried sticks, were intoxicated, or committed theft or violence against individuals. Only the women, perhaps unaware of their husbands' reasons for moderation, seemed extraordinarily agitated. Reports from other parts of the colony are very satisfactory: everywhere, the emancipated remained at their work.</tei-p>
</tei-div>

<tei-div data-origname="div">
  <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#HO" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">HONDURAS</tei-placeName>.</tei-head>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">The schooner <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Pincher</tei-emph>, commanded by <tei-persName ref="#BO" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Lieutenant Bolton</tei-persName>, departed from <tei-placeName ref="#JA" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Jamaica</tei-placeName> on <tei-date data-origname="date">August 15</tei-date> and encountered a slave ship near <tei-placeName ref="#CapM" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Cape Mase</tei-placeName> bound for <tei-placeName ref="#LA" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Havana</tei-placeName>. After a brief skirmish, during which the slaver lost its mast, the vessel, carrying 190 enslaved individuals, was captured and brought to <tei-placeName ref="#NP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">New Providence</tei-emph></tei-placeName>.</tei-p>
</tei-div>

<tei-div data-origname="div">
  <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#SL" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">SIERRA LEONE</tei-placeName>.</tei-head>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">It is widely known that slavers here employ several 
  <tei-choice data-origname="choice">
    <tei-orig data-origname="orig">agens</tei-orig>
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">agents</tei-reg>
  </tei-choice>
  . These agents are tasked with purchasing ships, ostensibly for legitimate purposes, that were 
  <tei-choice data-origname="choice">
    <tei-orig data-origname="orig">capturé</tei-orig>
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">captured</tei-reg>
  </tei-choice>
  by the Royal Navy for engaging in the slave trade and confiscated by the regular commissions. As soon as the 
  <tei-choice data-origname="choice">
    <tei-orig data-origname="orig">bâtimens</tei-orig>
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">ships</tei-reg>
  </tei-choice>
  they acquire are repaired and well-provisioned, they return them to their original illicit purpose. They find English merchants in the colony who do not hesitate to supply them with all necessary goods for their expeditions, even though the true purpose of these goods is well known.</tei-p>
</tei-div>

<tei-div data-origname="div">
  <tei-p data-origname="p">No news has yet been received regarding the implementation or enforcement of the emancipation act in the <tei-placeName ref="#BAR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Barbados</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName ref="#BA" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Bahamas</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName ref="#DOM" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Dominica</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName ref="#MO" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Montserrat</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName ref="#T" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Tobago</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName ref="#TO" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Tortola</tei-placeName>, and <tei-placeName ref="#NI" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Nevis</tei-placeName>. These British possessions, which all enjoy the 
  <tei-choice data-origname="choice">
    <tei-orig data-origname="orig">privilége</tei-orig>
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">privilege</tei-reg>
  </tei-choice>
  of electing their 
  <tei-choice data-origname="choice">
    <tei-orig data-origname="orig">représentans</tei-orig>
    <tei-reg data-origname="reg">representatives</tei-reg>
  </tei-choice>
  , are collectively referred to by the British as <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">chartered colonies</tei-emph></tei-foreign>, a term that might be translated as the old French expression *pays d'état*.</tei-p>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">The other British colonies (<tei-foreign data-origname="foreign"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">the crown colonies</tei-emph></tei-foreign>), including <tei-placeName ref="#TR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Trinidad</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName ref="#STL" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saint Lucia</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName ref="#DE" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Demerara</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName ref="#BER" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Berbice</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName ref="#HO" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Honduras</tei-placeName>, and <tei-placeName ref="#IM" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Mauritius</tei-placeName>, are subject to governance by ordinances.</tei-p>
</tei-div>
<tei-div xml:id="bibliography" id="bibliography" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
  <tei-head data-origname="head">BIBLIOGRAPHY</tei-head>

  <tei-head data-origname="head">APPEAL TO THE FRIENDS OF HUMANITY AGAINST A DREADFUL JUDGMENT, brochure in-8, by Mr. <tei-persName ref="#LFab" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">FABIEN</tei-persName>.</tei-head>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">There are so many forms of humanity, and it is so often shaped by circumstances, that despite the sense of shock provoked by the recent judgment of the royal court of <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName> in the <tei-placeName ref="#GdA" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Grand' Anse</tei-placeName> case—a sentiment both general and profound—Mr. Fabien deserves gratitude for his fervent plea on behalf of his brothers. This writing is vivid and passionate; yet, it is vivid without bitterness and passionate without overexcitement. It stands as a protest against forty death sentences. When one considers that an immense revolution unfolded in <tei-placeName ref="#FR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">France</tei-placeName> without a single execution, one cannot help but question the social necessity of these judicial saturnalias, which recur sporadically across the seas. Forty lives to atone for an indefinable riot—this, to borrow the powerful expression of a renowned orator, is enough to demoralize the concept of punishment itself.</tei-p>

  <tei-p data-origname="p">To commend Mr. Fabien for the restraint and propriety he maintained on such a sensitive issue is to recognize, beyond the merit of his noble defense, his ability to transcend all personal resentment. It has been his destiny to triumph over unlawful violence, and thus, it is with the authority of his name and his victories that he raises his voice on behalf of the condemned from <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Grand' Anse</tei-emph>. With him, we appeal to humanity—humanity in all times and places—not the kind upheld by certain individuals who have found an “honorable” proportion between the number of convictions and the number of accused. Indeed, what is as remarkable as the judgment itself is that one press outlet (a lone supporter of the colonial aristocracy) found the judgment to be <tei-emph data-origname="emph">filled with humanity</tei-emph>.</tei-p>
</tei-div>
   <tei-div data-origname="div"><tei-p data-origname="p">IMPRIMERIE D'HERHAN, 580, RUE SAINT-DENIS.</tei-p></tei-div>
</tei-div>
</tei-body>
   <tei-back data-origname="back">
      <tei-div xml:id="entities" id="entities" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-listPerson data-origname="listPerson">
        <tei-person xml:id="ROMA" id="ROMA" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Romagé the Ungovernable</tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Romagé l'Inregigible</tei-persName>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#jessica" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Romagé, also known as Romager, was one of the central figures in a series of dueling incidents that took place between white Creole colonists and free people of color in the colonies during the 1830s. These frequent clashes between the two groups were fueled by both personal disputes and collective solidarities.  </tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">At the end of 1833, on the evening of November 3, Romagé, while returning from a performance, is said to have confronted a man of color. The altercation that ensued reportedly led to a significant gathering of free people of color. In the following days, tensions continued to escalate, resulting in multiple arrests, including that of Romagé.  </tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">The colonial authorities, specifically the Private Council of Guadeloupe, ultimately decided to banish those deemed responsible for instigating these disturbances from the canton of Pointe-à-Pitre. Romagé was among them and was placed under surveillance on the island of La Désirade.</tei-p>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#jessica" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                    <tei-span lang="FR" style="font-family: 'Times',serif; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Calibri Light'; mso-bidi-theme-font: major-latin; color: black; mso-font-kerning: 0pt; mso-ligatures: none; mso-fareast-language: FR;" data-origname="span" data-origatts="style lang">Romagé ou Romager est l’un des protagonistes de l’une des affaires de duels survenues entre les colons blancs créoles des colonies et libres de couleur dans les années 1830. Les incidents entre les deux groupes qui se multiplient mêlent conflits personnels et solidarités de groupes. À la fin de l’année 1833, dans la soirée du 3 novembre, Romagé, rentrant du spectacle, aurait apostrophé un homme de couleur. L’altercation qui s’en suivit aurait entraîné un rassemblement considérable de libres de couleur. Dans les jours qui suivent, les conflits se poursuivent et donnent lieu à plusieurs arrestations, dont Romagé. Les autorités, en l’occurrence le Conseil Privé, de la Guadeloupe, décident d’exclure du canton de Pointe-à-Pitre ceux qui avaient été à l’origine de ces altercations. C’est le cas de Romagé mis en surveillance à la Désirade. </tei-span>
                </tei-p>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Adélaïde-Merlande, Jacques, « Libres et affranchis - réformes et tensions » dans  <tei-title data-origname="title">Historial Antillais</tei-title>  , Tome III, Dajani éditions, Pointe-à-Pitre, 1981 pp. 287-307</tei-bibl>
            </tei-note>
        </tei-person>
        <tei-person xml:id="ADA" id="ADA" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">John Adams</tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">John Adams</tei-persName>
            <tei-birth data-origname="birth">1735</tei-birth>
            <tei-death data-origname="death">1826</tei-death>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#masha #michaël" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">John Adams stands out among the first American presidents as a northerner who was never an enslaver. In the immediate aftermath of the American Revolution, he opposed efforts to implement large-scale emancipation in his home state of Massachusetts, but, as primary author of the state’s constitution, which included a Declaration of Rights (written after Adams served as Envoy to France), Adams has long been associated with the state’s de facto abolition in 1780. It was only after the 1781 cases of Mum Bett and Quok Walker, enslaved people who cited the language of the constitution in suing for their freedom, that the document, which does not explicitly prohibit slavery, took on this accepted meaning. </tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">John Adams’s presidency is notably marked by the establishment of trade relations with Haiti, which was then in conflict with France.  These political positions, in combination with an 1801 letter in which he expresses “abhorrence” to the institution of slavery, claiming to have always employed free men at significant personal expense, have contributed to Adams’ enduring legacy as a committed abolitionist. Recently, historians have called attention to the ways in which his positions were more in line with contemporaries, noting both that, with regard to Haiti, agreement to continue commerce is hardly a statement of ideological sympathy, and that any actual belief in the principle of equality was never public or explicit.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                </tei-p>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl" data-empty=""/>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Rossignol, Marie-Jeanne and Michaël Roy, with Marlene L. Daut and Cécile Roudeau, eds.  <tei-title data-origname="title">Anthologie de la pensée noire. États-Unis et Haïti (xviiie-xixe siècles)</tei-title>  . Marseille: Hors d’atteinte, 2023.</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">McCullough, David.  <tei-title data-origname="title">John Adams</tei-title>  . New York: Simon & Schuster, 2001.</tei-bibl>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#masha #michaël" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">John Adams est originaire du Nord des États-Unis et n’a jamais possédé d’esclaves, ce qui le distingue des premiers présidents américains. Bien qu’opposé à l’émancipation générale des esclaves dans son État natal du Massachusetts après la Révolution, il rédige pour le jeune État une constitution qui comprend une Déclaration des droits (il rentre alors d’une mission diplomatique en France) et œuvre de fait à la disparition progressive de l’esclavage dans le Massachusetts. Dans les années qui suivent l’adoption de la constitution en 1780, des personnes esclavisées telles que Mum Bett et Quok Walker n'hésitent pas à invoquer ce document pour poursuivre leur maître et réclamer leur liberté devant les tribunaux.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Le mandat de John Adams est notamment marqué par l’établissement de relations commerciales avec Haïti, alors en conflit avec la France. Ses prises de position politiques, ainsi qu’une lettre de 1801 dans laquelle il exprime sa « détestation » de l’esclavage et affirme avoir toujours employé des hommes libres, même lorsque le coût de leur travail était élevé, ont largement contribué à forger sa réputation d’abolitionniste engagé.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Cette image a toutefois été nuancée par l’historiographie récente, qui souligne la proximité d’Adams avec ses contemporains sur la question de l’esclavage. Le maintien des échanges avec Haïti, par exemple, ne traduit pas nécessairement une sympathie à l’égard de l’indépendance haïtienne, et Adams ne s’est jamais publiquement ni explicitement exprimé en faveur de l’égalité raciale.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                </tei-p>
            </tei-note>
        </tei-person>
        <tei-person xml:id="CIC" id="CIC" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Louis Marie Ambroise Dieudonné Cicéron</tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Louis Marie Ambroise Dieudonné Cicéron</tei-persName>
            <tei-birth data-origname="birth">1797</tei-birth>
            <tei-death data-origname="death">1870</tei-death>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#other #abel" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">The son of Ambroise Cicéron, a white Guadeloupean Creole notary,and Marie Victoire Artaud, Louis Marie Ambroise Dieudonné Cicéron was born in Saint-Pierre on September 25, 1797 and died on April 11, 1870 in the same city. He began practicing law in 1821, earned a bachelor of arts degree in 1822, became a lawyer and proprietor in 1825, was admitted to the royal court of Martinique and the court of 1era authority of Saint-Pierre in 1827, and was, between 1843 and 1844, a  colonial advisor and member of the municipal council of Saint-Pierre. As a defender of slavery, Ciceron was a political enemy of Cyrille Bissette through the 1830s; in October 1834, the two dueled in the Bois de Vincennes. Their political enmity is perceptible in several articles by Ciceron published in Journal du Havre in 1831, widely repeated in his “Petition to the King, to the nation and to the chambers” (dated January 1, 1832). Bissette responded to him in a letter dated May 15, 1833. In 1844, Cicero, present in Paris, acted as rapporteur for the “Observations of a special commission of the Colonial Council of Martinique on the bill presented on May 14 to the Chamber of Peers.”. These observations, signed by Le Pelletier-Duclary, president of the Colonial Council, concerned a bill for the abolition of slavery in the French colonies, refuting it point by point. Bissette's apparent good will towards former enslavers after the abolition of May 1848, and his association with the colonist Pécoul around legislative elections of 1849, brought him closer to Ciceron, whom he visited upon his return to Martinique on March 20, 1849.</tei-p>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#other #abel" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Fils du notaire blanc créole guadeloupéen, Ambroise Cicéron et de Marie Victoire Artaud, Louis Marie Ambroise Dieudonné Cicéron est né à Saint-Pierre le 25 septembre 1797 et meurt le 11 avril 1870 en la même ville. Il est qualifié de praticien en 1821, étudiant en droit bachelier ès lettres (1822), avocat et propriétaire (1825), avocat avoué près la cour royale de la Martinique et le tribunal de 1ère instance de Saint-Pierre (1827), conseiller colonial, membre du conseil municipal de Saint-Pierre et propriétaire en cette ville (1843-1844). Partisan du maintien du système esclavagiste, Louis Cicéron est opposé à Cyrille Bissette durant les années 1830-1840. Il se bat d’ailleurs en duel en octobre 1834 avec Bissette au bois de Vincennes. Leur inimitié politique est perceptible dans plusieurs articles de Cicéron publiés au journal du Havre en 1831, repris largement dans sa “Pétition au Roi, à la nation et aux chambres” (datée du 1er janvier 1832). Bissette lui répond dans une lettre du 15 mai 1833 ensuite. En 1844, Cicéron, présent à Paris, se fait le rapporteur des “Observations d’une commission spéciale du Conseil colonial de la Martinique sur le projet de loi présenté le 14 mai dernier à la Chambre des Pairs. Paris : Impr. de Bruneau, 1844”. Ces “observations, signées de Le Pelletier-Duclary, président du Conseil colonial, portaient sur le projet de loi du 14 mai 1844, visant à l’abolition de l’esclavage dans les colonies françaises, et le réfutant article après article...”. Le retournement de veste de Bissette vis-à-vis des colons esclavagistes après l’abolition de l’esclavage en mai 1848, son association avec le colon Pécoul en vue des élections législatives de 1849, le fit se rapprocher de Cicéron qu’il visita dès son arrivée en Martinique le 20 mars 1849.</tei-p>
            </tei-note>
        </tei-person>
        <tei-person xml:id="RS" id="RS" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Viscount Rosily</tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Le vicomte de Rosily</tei-persName>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#abel" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p" data-empty=""/>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Viscount Rosily served as Director of the Interior in Martinique at the time of the Grande Anse affair in December 1833, which was later tried by the Court of Assizes in Saint-Pierre in June 1834. As such, he was responsible for the administration of the island, overseeing matters ranging from general and sanitary policing to the management of direct and indirect taxation.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">He is mentioned in the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Revue des Colonies</tei-emph> because Cyrille Bissette, in 1834, directly accused the colonial authorities—Governor Dupotet, Director of the Interior Rosily, the district commander of Grande Anse, Desabaye, and the commander of the Saint-Pierre garrison, de Montigny—calling for the prosecution of these four men.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">In the Pointe-à-Pitre affair described in the first issue of the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Revue des Colonies</tei-emph>, viscount Rosily advocated for the expulsion of the accused individuals who were free. However, he was more reluctant when it came to expelling enslaved individuals accused of various offenses, such as marronage or poisoning. He viewed the deportation of enslaved people as a potential danger to the colony, arguing that such measures might encourage others to commit crimes.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                </tei-p>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Pâme, Stella.  <tei-title data-origname="title">Cyrille Bissette: un martyr de la liberté</tei-title> . Fort-de-France, Martinique: Editions Désormeaux, 1999.</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Oudin Bastide, Caroline,  <tei-title data-origname="title">Des nègres et des juges : La scandaleuse affaire Spoutourne (1831-1834)</tei-title>   <tei-emph data-origname="emph">, </tei-emph> Paris, Editions Complexe, 2008</tei-bibl>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#abel" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Le vicomte de Rosily est directeur de l’Intérieur en Martinique au moment de l’affaire de la Grande Anse, survenue en décembre 1833 et jugée par la Cour d’assises de Saint-Pierre en juin 1834. À ce titre, il est chargé de l’administration de l’île, ses attributions couvrant aussi bien la police générale et sanitaire que la gestion des contributions directes et indirectes.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">S’il est mentionné dans la <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Revue des Colonies</tei-emph>, c’est parce que Cyrille Bissette, en 1834, accuse directement les autorités coloniales de complicité et réclame la mise en accusation de quatre hauts responsables : le gouverneur Dupotet, le directeur de l’Intérieur Rosily, le commandant du quartier de la Grande Anse, Desabaye, et le commandant de la garnison de Saint-Pierre, de Montigny.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Dans l’affaire de Pointe-à-Pitre, relatée dans le premier numéro de la <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Revue des Colonies</tei-emph>, le vicomte de Rosily se prononce en faveur de l’expulsion des accusés libres. Toutefois, il se montre plus réservé quant à l’exil des esclaves impliqués dans divers délits, tels que le marronnage ou l’empoisonnement. Selon lui, la déportation des esclaves constitue une menace pour la colonie, car une telle mesure pourrait les encourager à commettre d’autres crimes.</tei-p>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Pâme, Stella.  <tei-title data-origname="title">Cyrille Bissette: un martyr de la liberté</tei-title> . Fort-de-France, Martinique: Editions Désormeaux, 1999.</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Oudin Bastide, Caroline,  <tei-title data-origname="title">Des nègres et des juges : La scandaleuse affaire Spoutourne (1831-1834)</tei-title>   <tei-emph data-origname="emph">, </tei-emph> Paris, Editions Complexe, 2008</tei-bibl>
            </tei-note>
        </tei-person>
        <tei-person xml:id="SebPC" id="SebPC" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Sébastien Privat Caffié </tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Sébastien Privat Caffié </tei-persName>
            <tei-birth data-origname="birth">1786</tei-birth>
            <tei-death data-origname="death">1848</tei-death>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#jessica" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Sébastien Privat Caffié was a landowner who married Marie Rose Catherine Paret in Gros-Morne, Martinique, on June 12, 1821. A commissioner-commander, he was elected mayor of the commune of Trinité in 1847.</tei-p>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#jessica" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                    <tei-span lang="FR" style="font-family: 'Times',serif; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Calibri Light'; mso-bidi-theme-font: major-latin; color: black; mso-font-kerning: 0pt; mso-ligatures: none; mso-fareast-language: FR;" data-origname="span" data-origatts="style lang">Sébastien Privat Caffié est un propriétaire, marié à Marie Rose Catherien Paret au Gros-Morne (Martinique) le 12 juin 1821. Commissaire-commandant, il est élu maire de la commune de Trinité en 1847.</tei-span>
                </tei-p>

        <tei-person xml:id="LePell" id="LePell" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Jean-Baptiste François Le Pelletier-Duclary</tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Jean-Baptiste François Le Pelletier-Duclary</tei-persName>
            <tei-birth data-origname="birth">1791 or 1793</tei-birth>
            <tei-death data-origname="death">1865</tei-death>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#abel" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Lawyer at the court of Paris, assessor to the Superior Council of Martinique (took offic 1819), councilor to the Royal Court of Martinique (May 9, 1821, confirmed October 5 1828), of which he became president in January 1835, knight of the Legion of Honor (January 16, 1836), president of the Colonial Council of Martinique from 1834 to 1838 and from 1839 to 1847. He married Marie Elisabeth Nelly Cornette de Saint-Cyr, a white Creole woman on June 11, 1821 in Case Pilote. Like many white settlers, he refused any reformation of the slave system, particularly in favor of equality for free people of color. He was one of the members of the Assize Court of Saint-Pierre chaired by de Perinelle who judged the 173 individuals accused during the Grande Anse affair (Lorrain) of December 1833. He shared quite naturally the prejudices and principles inherent in the mentality and social group of the powerful white families of the colony who made up the colonial judiciary between the decades of 1820 and 1840. </tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                </tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">https://www.patrimoines-martinique.org/ark:/35569/w6lcx297j5p0/c1f43fd7-b3e2-4d32-b04f-d620bbbbf54e</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">https://man8rove.com/en/profile/eql4p4vv1-jean-baptiste-francois-le-pelletier-du-clary</tei-p>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#abel" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Né le 26 décembre 1791 ou le 28 janvier 1793 à Case-Pilote en Martinique selon les sources consultées, décédé le 12 juillet 1865 à Case-Pilote, habitant propriétaire domicilié dans cette paroisse et quartier, avocat à la cour de Paris, assesseur au Conseil supérieur de la Martinique en fonctions en 1819, conseiller à la Cour royale de la Martinique (9 mai 1821, confirmé le 5 octobre 1828) dont il est président en janvier 1835, chevalier de la légion d’honneur (16 janvier 1836), président du Conseil colonial de la Martinique de 1834 à 1838 et de 1839 à 1847. Il épouse à Case-Pilote, Marie Elisabeth Nelly Cornette de Saint-Cyr, blanche créole, le 11 juin 1821. Il est l’incarnation même des colons, blancs créoles, refusant toute évolution du système esclavagiste notamment en faveur de l’égalité pour les libres de couleur. Il fait partie des membres de la Cour d’assises de Saint-Pierre présidée par de Perinelle qui juge au début du mois de juin 1834 les 173 individus accusés lors de l’affaire de la Grande Anse (Lorrain) en décembre 1833. Il partage tout naturellement les préjugés et les principes inhérents à la mentalité et au groupe social des grandes familles blanches de la colonie qui composent la magistrature coloniale entre les décennies 1820 et 1840.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                </tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">https://www.patrimoines-martinique.org/ark:/35569/w6lcx297j5p0/c1f43fd7-b3e2-4d32-b04f-d620bbbbf54e</tei-p>

        <tei-person xml:id="MACK" id="MACK" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Ange René Armand, baron de Mackau</tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Ange René Armand, baron de Mackau</tei-persName>
            <tei-birth data-origname="birth">1788</tei-birth>
            <tei-death data-origname="death">1855</tei-death>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#chelsea" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                    <tei-span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-font-kerning: 0pt; mso-ligatures: none;" data-origname="span" data-origatts="style">Baron Ange-René-Armand de Mackau had a long career in the navy in various French colonies. He was chosen as Charles X’s envoy to Haiti to deliver—backed by a fleet of 14 warships—the 1825 ordonnance to Haitian president Jean-Pierre Boyer. He later became minister of the navy and colonies. In his new role, he proposed set of gradualist laws in anticipation of the abolition of slavery in the French colonies. The 1845 Mackau laws, as they came to be known, improved conditions for the enslaved, promoted their access to religious instruction, and allowed for the practice of buying one’s freedom or the freedom of one’s kin (<tei-emph data-origname="emph">rachat</tei-emph>). Though many lauded the laws, Bissette attacked the laws swiftly and vehemently in his writings for their gradualist approach. </tei-span>
                </tei-p>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#chelsea" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Le baron Ange-René-Armand de Mackau fait carrière dans la marine et exerce diverses fonctions dans les colonies françaises. Il est choisi comme émissaire de Charles X auprès d’Haïti pour remettre, à la tête d’une flotte de quatorze navires de guerre, l’ordonnance de 1825 au président haïtien Jean-Pierre Boyer. Par la suite, il devient ministre de la Marine et des Colonies. À ce poste, il propose une série de lois réformistes en prévision de l’abolition de l’esclavage dans les colonies françaises. Les lois Mackau de 1845, comme elles seront appelées, visent à améliorer les conditions de vie des personnes réduites en esclavage, à favoriser leur accès à l’instruction religieuse et à encadrer la possibilité de rachat, leur permettant ainsi d’acheter leur liberté ou celle de leurs proches. Si ces mesures sont largement saluées, Bissette les condamne avec vigueur dans ses écrits, dénonçant leur gradualisme.</tei-p>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Dorigny, Marcel; Bruffaerts, Jean-Claude; Gaillard, Gusti-Klara; et Théodat, Jean-Marie, eds.,  <tei-title data-origname="title">Haïti-France. Les chaînes de la dette. Le rapport Mackau (1825)</tei-title>  . Hémisphères Éditions, 2022.</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Jennings, Lawrence C.  <tei-title data-origname="title">French Anti-Slavery: The Movement for the Abolition of Slavery in France, 1802-1848</tei-title> . Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000. 29-37, 49-50, 71-73, 266-69.</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Schmidt, Nelly.  <tei-title data-origname="title">Abolitionnistes de l'esclavage et réformateurs des colonies, 1820-1851: analyses et documents</tei-title> . Paris: Karthala, 2000.</tei-bibl>
            </tei-note>
        </tei-person>
        <tei-person xml:id="ANog" id="ANog" data-origname="person" data-origatts="xml:id">
            <tei-persName xml:lang="en" lang="en" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Arsène Nogues</tei-persName>
            <tei-persName xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="xml:lang">Arsène Nogues</tei-persName>
            <tei-birth data-origname="birth">1798</tei-birth>
            <tei-death data-origname="death">1869</tei-death>
            <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="Person" resp="#abel" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Born in Redon on June 12, 1798, Arsene Nogues held various positions in Brest and Nancy and was also attorney general in Guadeloupe then in Martinique during the 1830s. Later, he was advisor to the royal court of Rouen in 1845. Married to the daughter of a coffee merchant and planter of Guadeloupean origin, Jean Joseph Albert Chaviteau, who settled in Cuba at the beginning of the 19th century, Nogues had strong ties to the planter community. Nogues represented the public prosecutor as attorney general during the Grande Anse affair in December 1833. The indictment prepared by Nogues in June 1834, recovered by the historian Armand Nicolas describes the events thusly: “It is an armed insurrection, prepared for a long time... by almost the entire colored population of a district of the colony, with whom conspirators from another district and even from several others had colluded to carry out the pillage, devastation and burning of the colony, to massacre all the whites there in order to seize their property.” The members of the Assize Court of Saint-Pierre, presided over by de Perinelle and composed of advisors Richard de Lucy, Le Pelletier, and Duclary, the same ones who condemned Bissette and his comrades, were all white Creoles. They sentenced 141 individuals of color to various punishments.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                </tei-p>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Nicolas, Armand,  <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Histoire de la Martinique, Des Arawaks à 1848</tei-emph> , Paris, L’Harmattan, 1996</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">"Arsène Nogues,"  <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Man8rove.</tei-emph>  https://man8rove.com/fr/profile/a1r52vc3-arsene-nogues</tei-bibl>
                <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">"CHAUVITEAU Jean Joseph Albert (1775-1823),"  <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Cimetière du Père-Lachaise</tei-emph> , 3 septembre 2023, https://www.appl-lachaise.net/chauviteau-jean-joseph-albert-1775-1823/</tei-bibl>
            </tei-note>
            <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="Person" resp="#abel" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type xml:lang">
                <tei-p data-origname="p">Né à Redon le 12 juin 1798, il occupe divers postes à Brest et à Nancy et est aussi procureur général en Guadeloupe puis en Martinique durant les années 1830. Puis, il est ensuite conseiller à la cour royale de Rouen en 1845. Marié à la fille d’un négociant et planteur de café d’origine guadeloupéenne, Jean Joseph Albert Chaviteau, qui se fixa à Cuba au début du XIXe siècle, il est donc lié fortement au milieu des colons. Arsène Nogues, est celui qui représente le ministère public en tant que procureur général lors de l’affaire de la Grande Anse (commune du Lorrain aujourd’hui) en décembre 1833. L’historien Armand Nicolas cite ainsi l’acte d’accusation en juin 1834 que Arsène Nogues dresse en notifiant que : “C’est une insurrection à main armée, préparée depuis longtemps... par la presque totalité de la population de couleur d’un quartier de la colonie, avec laquelle des conspirateurs d’un autre quartier et même de plusieurs autres s’étaient entendus pour porter le pillage, la dévastation et l’incendie de la colonie, pour y massacrer tous les Blancs afin de s’emparer de leurs biens”. Au nombre des membres de la Cour d’Assises de Saint-Pierre présidée par de Perinelle et composée de conseillers (Richard de Lucy, Le Pelletier Duclary), tous blancs créoles, les mêmes qui ont condamné Bissette et ses camarades, se trouve donc des hommes imbus de leurs pouvoirs discrétionnaires. Ils vont condamner 141 individus de couleur à diverses peines.</tei-p>
                <tei-p data-origname="p">
                </tei-p>

            </tei-note>
